quote: Often does hatred hurt itself
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Often does hatred hurt itself
summary: The quote "Often does hatred hurt itself" means that when you hold onto strong negative feelings like hatred towards others, you frequently end up causing more harm to yourself than to the person you dislike. This is because hatred is a powerful, destructive emotion that can consume your thoughts, fill you with anger and bitterness, and steal your peace of mind. Instead of hurting the target of your hatred, it often makes *you* unhappy, stressed, and focused on negativity. Essentially, the person who suffers most from hatred is usually the one who feels it.

summary: This quote suggests that life's most important journeys, much like great stories, are often full of immense challenges and dangers. During these difficult times, it's natural to feel despair, wondering how things could possibly end well or return to normal after so much bad has happened. However, the message offers hope: this period of darkness and suffering is only temporary. It's a passing thing, and eventually, even the deepest gloom will give way to light.

quote: For like a shaft, clear and cold, the thought pierced him that in the end the Shadow was only a small and passing thing: there was light and high beauty for ever beyond its reach.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: For like a shaft, clear and cold, the thought pierced him that in the end the Shadow was only a small and passing thing: there was light and high beauty for ever beyond its reach.
summary: This quote describes a sudden, clear realization that even the darkest challenges or evils, referred to as "the Shadow," are ultimately small and temporary. This profound thought reveals that such negativity will eventually pass. More importantly, it highlights that beyond the reach of any darkness, there exists an eternal light and great beauty that will forever remain untouched and undiminished.

quote:
PIPPIN: I didn't think it would end this way.

GANDALF: End? No, the journey doesn't end here. Death is just another path, one that we all must take. The grey rain-curtain of this world rolls back, and all turns to silver glass, and then you see it.

PIPPIN: What? Gandalf? See what?

GANDALF: White shores, and beyond, a far green country under a swift sunrise.

PIPPIN: Well, that isn't so bad.

GANDALF: No. No, it isn't.

He describes this transition beautifully, explaining that the world transforms, revealing a peaceful and bright afterlife, like "white shores" and a "far green country" under a new sunrise. Hearing this comforting vision, Pippin's initial fear turns to relief, realizing that such an end isn't bad at all.

quote: I have claimed that Escape is one of the main functions of fairy-stories, and since I do not disapprove of them, it is plain that I do not accept the tone of scorn or pity with which 'Escape' is now so often used. Why should a man be scorned if, finding himself in prison, he tries to get out and go home? Or if he cannot do so, he thinks and talks about other topics than jailers and prison-walls?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I have claimed that Escape is one of the main functions of fairy-stories, and since I do not disapprove of them, it is plain that I do not accept the tone of scorn or pity with which 'Escape' is now so often used. Why should a man be scorned if, finding himself in prison, he tries to get out and go home? Or if he cannot do so, he thinks and talks about other topics than jailers and prison-walls?
summary: The author believes that one of the main purposes of fairy tales is to offer "escape," and he sees this as a positive thing, not something to be looked down upon. He rejects the idea that "escape" should be treated with scorn or pity. To illustrate his point, he asks why anyone would criticize a person in prison for trying to get out and go home, or for simply thinking about things other than their jailers and walls. He implies that real life can sometimes feel like a "prison," and seeking escape, even through stories, is a natural and understandable human desire.

quote: I warn you, if you bore me, I shall take my revenge.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I warn you, if you bore me, I shall take my revenge.
summary: This quote is a direct and serious warning from the speaker. They are making it very clear that if you fail to keep them interested and instead cause them boredom, there will be negative consequences. Essentially, they expect to be entertained or engaged, and if you don't meet that expectation, they will find a way to get back at you or retaliate in some manner.

quote: We have come from God, and inevitably the myths woven by us, though they contain error, will also reflect a splintered fragment of the true light, the eternal truth that is with God. Indeed only by myth-making, only by becoming 'sub-creator' and inventing stories, can Man aspire to the state of perfection that he knew before the Fall. Our myths may be misguided, but they steer however shakily towards the true harbour, while materialistic 'progress' leads only to a yawning abyss and the Iron Crown of the power of evil.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We have come from God, and inevitably the myths woven by us, though they contain error, will also reflect a splintered fragment of the true light, the eternal truth that is with God. Indeed only by myth-making, only by becoming 'sub-creator' and inventing stories, can Man aspire to the state of perfection that he knew before the Fall. Our myths may be misguided, but they steer however shakily towards the true harbour, while materialistic 'progress' leads only to a yawning abyss and the Iron Crown of the power of evil.
summary: This quote suggests that because humanity comes from God, the stories and myths we create, even if flawed, naturally contain a small piece of God's eternal truth. By making up stories and acting as "sub-creators," humans try to reach the perfect state they once knew. While our myths might be imperfect, they still guide us, however shakily, towards genuine truth. In stark contrast, the quote warns that focusing only on material 'progress' leads only to emptiness and the power of evil.

quote:
Roads Go Ever On

Roads go ever ever on,
Over rock and under tree,
By caves where never sun has shone,
By streams that never find the sea;
Over snow by winter sown,
And through the merry flowers of June,
Over grass and over stone,
And under mountains in the moon.

Roads go ever ever on,
Under cloud and under star.
Yet feet that wandering have gone
Turn at last to home afar.
Eyes that fire and sword have seen,
And horror in the halls of stone
Look at last on meadows green,
And trees and hills they long have known.

The Road goes ever on and on
Down from the door where it began.
Now far ahead the Road has gone,
And I must follow, if I can,
Pursuing it with eager feet,
Until it joins some larger way,
Where many paths and errands meet.

The Road goes ever on and on
Down from the door where it began.
Now far ahead the Road has gone,
And I must follow, if I can,
Pursuing it with weary feet,
Until it joins some larger way,
Where many paths and errands meet.
And whither then? I cannot say.

The Road goes ever on and on
Out from the door where it began.
Now far ahead the Road has gone.
Let others follow, if they can!
Let them a journey new begin.
But I at last with weary feet
Will turn towards the lighted inn,
My evening-rest and sleep to meet.

summary: This poem describes roads as endless paths that stretch across all types of terrain—from rocky mountains and dark caves to sunny meadows and snowy fields, covering every season and time. While roads invite people to journey far, the poem notes that even the most seasoned travelers eventually long to return home, seeking comfort and peace after seeing much of the world. The speaker then reflects on their own life's journey, which began at their front door. They describe following this path with eager enthusiasm at first, but later with tired feet, recognizing that their personal road, like all roads, goes on and on. Ultimately, the speaker anticipates their long journey concluding at a "lighted inn," symbolizing a desired final rest and peace after a long life's travels.

quote: You can only come to the morning through the shadows.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: You can only come to the morning through the shadows.
summary: This quote means that you can only reach good times, success, or happiness (the "morning") by first going through difficulties, struggles, or challenges (the "shadows"). It suggests that experiencing tough periods is an essential part of life's journey. You can't skip the hard parts to get to the good parts; often, it's these very struggles that teach us, make us stronger, and help us truly appreciate the brighter moments when they arrive.

quote: Short cuts make long delays.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Short cuts make long delays.
summary: The quote "Short cuts make long delays" means that trying to finish a task quickly by avoiding proper steps or cutting corners often leads to more problems and wasted time in the long run. While you might think you're saving time initially, this approach usually results in mistakes, poor quality, or unforeseen complications that require even more effort and time to fix later on. Ultimately, doing something correctly from the start, even if it takes a bit longer, is usually more efficient than taking an easy way out that leads to significant setbacks.

quote:
All that is gold does not glitter,
Not all those who wander are lost.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All that is gold does not glitter,
Not all those who wander are lost.
summary: This quote means that you shouldn't judge things or people based only on how they appear on the surface. Something truly valuable might not look impressive or flashy, and someone who seems to be aimlessly exploring might actually be on a purposeful journey of discovery, rather than being truly lost. It's a reminder that appearances can be deceiving and that true worth or direction isn't always obvious.

quote: But I have been too deeply hurt, Sam. I tried to save the Shire, and it has been saved, but not for me. It must often be so, Sam, when things are in danger: some one has to give them up, lose them, so that others may keep them.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But I have been too deeply hurt, Sam. I tried to save the Shire, and it has been saved, but not for me. It must often be so, Sam, when things are in danger: some one has to give them up, lose them, so that others may keep them.
summary: The speaker feels profoundly damaged and unable to fully enjoy the peace they helped create, even though they successfully saved what was important to them. They believe this is a common truth: sometimes, when something valuable is in danger, someone has to make a personal sacrifice or give it up completely, so that others can keep and benefit from it.

quote:
It cannot be seen, cannot be felt,
Cannot be heard, cannot be smelt,
It lies behind stars and under hills,

It comes first and follows after,
Ends life, kills laughter.

summary: This quote describes something that is completely imperceptible to our senses – it cannot be seen, felt, heard, or smelled. It suggests that this mysterious entity is everywhere, existing in the vastness of space and deep within the earth, filling any empty space. The quote also implies its timeless nature, present at both the beginning and the end. Ultimately, it is portrayed as a powerful force associated with finality, death, and the loss of happiness.

quote:
Where did you go to, if I may ask?' said Thorin to Gandalf as they rode along.
To look ahead,' said he.
And what brought you back in the nick of time?'
Looking behind,' said he.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Where did you go to, if I may ask?' said Thorin to Gandalf as they rode along.
To look ahead,' said he.
And what brought you back in the nick of time?'
Looking behind,' said he.
summary: In this exchange, Thorin asks Gandalf about his mysterious comings and goings. Gandalf explains that he went away to "look ahead," meaning he was thinking about the future and preparing for what was to come. He then states that he returned "in the nick of time" because he was "looking behind," implying he was reflecting on past events, learning from them, or realizing the consequences that were now catching up. Essentially, the quote highlights that both foresight (planning for the future) and reflection (understanding the past) are crucial for making timely and effective decisions, especially during critical moments.

quote: In this hour, I do not believe that any darkness will endure.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In this hour, I do not believe that any darkness will endure.
summary: This quote expresses a strong sense of hope and conviction. It means that even in the current moment, which might be difficult or challenging, the speaker firmly believes that no amount of hardship, sadness, or negativity ('darkness') will last forever. They are confident that difficult times will eventually pass, suggesting a powerful faith in resilience and an optimistic outlook for the future.

quote: Oft hope is born when all is forlorn.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Oft hope is born when all is forlorn.
summary: This quote means that hope often appears even when circumstances seem utterly hopeless. It suggests that just when everything feels lost and there's no reason to be optimistic, a sense of hope can surprisingly emerge, offering a way forward even in the darkest times.

quote: The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.
summary: This quote means that the world and all its experiences are vast and constantly surround us. While we might try to isolate ourselves, limit our experiences, or avoid facing certain realities, it's ultimately impossible to completely or permanently shut out the wider world. Its influences, challenges, and realities will inevitably find their way in, no matter how much we try to build barriers around ourselves.

quote: I do not love the bright sword for its sharpness, nor the arrow for its swiftness, nor the warrior for his glory. I love only that which they defend.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I do not love the bright sword for its sharpness, nor the arrow for its swiftness, nor the warrior for his glory. I love only that which they defend.
summary: The speaker is saying that they don't admire weapons for their power or effectiveness, nor do they value warriors for their fame or heroic deeds. Instead, their love and admiration are reserved solely for the cause or the people that these instruments and individuals are used to protect. In essence, the speaker values what is defended, not the act of defense itself or the tools used for it.

quote: He that breaks a thing to find out what it is has left the path of wisdom.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: He that breaks a thing to find out what it is has left the path of wisdom.
summary: This quote suggests that it is not wise to destroy something in order to understand how it works or what it is. True wisdom involves seeking knowledge through more careful and respectful methods, rather than causing harm or irreversible damage. Essentially, breaking something apart just to satisfy curiosity is portrayed as a foolish or misguided approach to learning.

quote:
Home is behind, the world ahead,
And there are many paths to tread
Through shadows to the edge of night,
Until the stars are all alight.
Then world behind and home ahead,
We'll wander back and home to bed.
Mist and twilight, cloud and shade,
Away shall fade! Away shall fade!

Until the stars are all alight.
Then world behind and home ahead,
We'll wander back and home to bed.
Mist and twilight, cloud and shade,

summary: This quote describes life as a journey that begins when we leave the comfort and familiarity of home to explore the wide world. Along this path, we will encounter many choices and challenges, represented by "shadows" and the "edge of night," until we reach a point of completion or understanding. After this adventure, the journey ends, and we find our way back to the peace and rest of home. Ultimately, all the difficulties, uncertainties, and struggles faced during the journey will eventually disappear and fade away.

quote: There is more in you of good than you know, child of the kindly West. Some courage and some wisdom, blended in measure. If more of us valued food and cheer and song above hoarded gold, it would be a merrier world.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: There is more in you of good than you know, child of the kindly West. Some courage and some wisdom, blended in measure. If more of us valued food and cheer and song above hoarded gold, it would be a merrier world.
summary: This quote suggests that people often don't realize how much good, courage, and wisdom they already possess within themselves. It then argues that if we, as a society, valued simple joys like good food, happiness, and music more than accumulating wealth and material possessions, the world would be a much happier and more joyful place for everyone.

quote:
Good Morning!" said Bilbo, and he meant it. The sun was shining, and the grass was very green. But Gandalf looked at him from under long bushy eyebrows that stuck out further than the brim of his shady hat.

"What do you mean?" he said. "Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I want it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on?"

"All of them at once," said Bilbo. "And a very fine morning for a pipe of tobacco out of doors, into the bargain.

...

"Good morning!" he said at last. "We don't want any adventures here, thank you! You might try over The Hill or across The Water." By this he meant that the conversation was at an end.
"What a lot of things you do use Good morning for!" said Gandalf. "Now you mean that you want to get rid of me, and that it won't be good till I move off.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Good Morning!" said Bilbo, and he meant it. The sun was shining, and the grass was very green. But Gandalf looked at him from under long bushy eyebrows that stuck out further than the brim of his shady hat.

"What do you mean?" he said. "Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I want it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on?"

"All of them at once," said Bilbo. "And a very fine morning for a pipe of tobacco out of doors, into the bargain.

...

"Good morning!" he said at last. "We don't want any adventures here, thank you! You might try over The Hill or across The Water." By this he meant that the conversation was at an end.
"What a lot of things you do use Good morning for!" said Gandalf. "Now you mean that you want to get rid of me, and that it won't be good till I move off.
summary: This quote shows how a seemingly simple greeting like "Good Morning" can have many different meanings depending on the situation and the speaker's true feelings. Initially, Bilbo uses it sincerely to express his happiness with the sunny weather and his desire for a calm, peaceful morning. However, Gandalf immediately questions the various ways the phrase could be interpreted. Later, Bilbo uses "Good Morning" again, but this time it's a polite way to tell Gandalf to leave because Bilbo doesn't want any adventures. Gandalf then points out this shift, highlighting how a common pleasantry can subtly convey anything from genuine cheer to a desire for someone to go away.

quote: In sorrow we must go, but not in despair. Behold! we are not bound for ever to the circles of the world, and beyond them is more than memory.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: In sorrow we must go, but not in despair. Behold! we are not bound for ever to the circles of the world, and beyond them is more than memory.
summary: This quote suggests that while we will all experience sadness in life, we should never lose hope or fall into despair. It reminds us that our time in this world is not endless, and there is something more profound and lasting waiting for us beyond our earthly existence, something greater than just memories of the past.
